name: autocomplete attribute: on & off values
description: The `autocomplete` attribute for `input` elements indicates to the browser whether a value should or should not be autofilled when appropriate.

notes.general:
This support information does not include support for other `autocomplete` values.

As described in detail below, many modern browsers ignore the `off` value on certain fields in certain cases intentionally in order to give the user more control over autofilling fields. One example is the use of password managers.

byNum.1: Partial support refers to ignoring the `off` value for password fields. [see related blog post](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2009/09/10/troubleshooting-stored-login-problems-in-ie.aspx)
byNum.2: Partial support in Chrome refers to the browser intentionally ignoring `autocomplete="off"` when the user uses the browser's autofill functionality. [see bug](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=468153#c29)
byNum.3: Partial support in Firefox refers to ignoring `autocomplete="off"` for login forms. [see bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=956906)
byNum.4: Browser does not display previously submitted values as options with `on` value.
byNum.5: Safari ignores the `off` value for [username, email and password fields](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22661977/disabling-safari-autofill-on-usernames-and-passwords)
